
## **The Clock is Ticking: How Do Americans Spend Their Time?** 
#### Authors: Jaeyeon Won (Project Coordinator), Becca Barrick, Jay Maxwell, Alec Meyer, and Tessa Mendoza


## **Introduction**
Every day, individuals in America differently allocate their time between various activities, such as work, leisure, personal care, socializing, and other activities. As understanding this individual time usage is a complicated task, exploring the their time usage as a whole can be helpful in obtaining the general picture on human activity. Practically, our paper could also be the most valuable resources for promoting social and economic activities performed in the United States, by providing informative analysis. With the purpose of gaining insight into how Americans spend their time, this project investigates the overall trends and patterns of their activity time use in relation to several interesting factors, using various visualizations.

![People in New York](https://offloadmedia.feverup.com/secretnyc.co/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/10132249/people-1024x597.jpg)

<hr>

## **Research Questions**
To achieve our goal, we have developed five general areas of exploration with the following five research questions: 

- What are the overall time usage patterns for different demographics?
- How did the trend of time usage change over the last 15 years? 
- How are individual's perceived life satisfaction and time usage related?
- How are individual's general health status and time usage related? 
- What factors are related to individual's work and travel time? 

<hr>

## **Overview of the Dataset**
This section describes how we obtained and cleaned the dataset for this project.

#### **Obtaining the Dataset**
The dataset *time.cvs* comes from the *IPUMS Time Use*, a collaborative research data portal that provides demographic, socioeconomic, household, and daily time use data from survey respondents. Specifically, the dataset was extracted from the *American Time Use Survey (ATUS)* (https://timeuse.ipums.org/), which provides U.S. time diary survey data for period since 2003, using the ATUS extract builder.

The extracted dataset contains 39 variables for approximately 189,866 observations collected from 2004 to 2019. 7 of them are time use variables that were used as response variables, and the other 32 are additional variables that were used to investigate the associations to the time use variables. 

#### **Cleaning the Datset**
The data cleaning process was made relatively simple by the ATUS extract builder, since we were able to export the dataset only with the necessary variables directly as a csv file. The categorical variables in the extracted dataset were encoded as numerical values. To clean this, we renamed the levels with appropriate names based on the codebook provided by the ATUS extract builder. 

Our dataset and the codebook can be found at https://github.com/tessamendoza/ds202_project.git.

## **Exploratory Analysis**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggthemes)
library(ggcorrplot)
library(ggpubr)
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
time = read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tessamendoza/ds202_project/main/time.csv")
statecode = read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tessamendoza/ds202_project/main/state_codes.csv")
states = map_data('state')
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
# overall data cleaning
statecode = statecode %>%
  mutate(STATE = tolower(STATE))
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
# clean data
time_jaeyeon = time %>%
  select(REGION, STATEFIP, AGE, SEX, RACE, starts_with('ACT_'))
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
# Independent variables

# SEX
# Convert type
time_jaeyeon$SEX = as.factor(time_jaeyeon$SEX)
# Rename the levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$SEX) =  c("Male", "Female")
# Check new levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$SEX)

# RACE
# Include only non-mixed races
time_jaeyeon = time_jaeyeon %>%
  filter(RACE %in% c(100, 110, 120, 131, 132))
# Convert type
time_jaeyeon$RACE = as.factor(time_jaeyeon$RACE)
# Rename the levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$RACE) =  c("White only", "Black only", "American Indian, Alaskan Native", "Asian only", "Hawaiian Pacific Islander only")
# Check new levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$RACE)

# REGION
# Convert type
time_jaeyeon$REGION = as.factor(time_jaeyeon$REGION)
# Rename the levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$REGION) =  c("Northeast", "Midwest", "South", "West")
# Check new levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$REGION)

# STATEFIP
# Join
time_jaeyeon = time_jaeyeon %>%
  left_join(statecode, by = "STATEFIP" )
# Convert type
time_jaeyeon$STATE = as.factor(time_jaeyeon$STATE)
# Check new levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$STATE)
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
# Dependent variables

# Pivot_longer
time_jaeyeon_longer = time_jaeyeon %>%
  pivot_longer(starts_with('ACT_'), names_to = 'TIME_ACTIVITY', values_to = 'TIME_SPENT')
# Convert type
time_jaeyeon_longer$TIME_ACTIVITY = as.factor(time_jaeyeon_longer$TIME_ACTIVITY)
# Rename the levels
levels(time_jaeyeon_longer$TIME_ACTIVITY) =  c("Eating & Drinking", 
                                "Personal Care", 
                                "Religious & Spiritual Activities", 
                                "Socializing, Relaxing & Leisure", 
                                "Sports, Exercise & Recreation", 
                                "Traveling", 
                                "Work & Work-Related Activities")
# Check new levels
levels(time_jaeyeon_longer$TIME_ACTIVITY)
```

**- How Does Time Usage Differ By Age Group?**
```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, fig.align='center'}
# Age Group
time_jaeyeon_longer = time_jaeyeon_longer %>%
  mutate(age_group = case_when(AGE >= 15  & AGE <= 19 ~ '15-19',
                              AGE >= 20  & AGE <= 29 ~ '20-29',
                              AGE >= 30  & AGE <= 39 ~ '30-39',
                              AGE >= 40  & AGE <= 49 ~ '40-49',
                              AGE >= 50  & AGE <= 59 ~ '50-59',
                              AGE >= 60  & AGE <= 69 ~ '60-69',
                              AGE >= 70  & AGE <= 79 ~ '70-79',
                              AGE >= 80  & AGE <= 89 ~ '80-89',
                              AGE >= 20  & AGE <= 29 ~ '20-29'))

# Proportional Barplot
time_jaeyeon_longer %>%
  group_by(age_group, TIME_ACTIVITY) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(TIME_SPENT)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = age_group, weight = avg_time, fill = TIME_ACTIVITY)) + 
  geom_bar(position = 'fill') +
  theme_bw() +
  ggtitle('Proportional Barplot of Time Usage by Age Group') +
  xlab('Activity') +
  ylab('Average Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(fill = 'Activity',
       caption = 'Figure 1: Proportional Bar Graph of Average Time Spent per Day by Age Group (in minutes)') +
  theme(plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        panel.background = element_blank(),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"))
```

**- How Does Time Usage Differ By Gender?**
```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, fig.align='center'}
# Side by Side Barplot
time_jaeyeon_longer %>%
  group_by(TIME_ACTIVITY, SEX) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(TIME_SPENT)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(TIME_ACTIVITY, avg_time), weight = avg_time, fill = SEX)) + 
  geom_bar(position = 'dodge') +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_bw() +
  ggtitle('Side-by-Side Barplot of Time Usage by Gender') +
  xlab('Activity') +
  ylab('Average Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(fill = 'Gender',
       caption = 'Figure 2: Side-by-Side Bar Graph of Average Time Spent per Day by Gender (in minutes)') +
  theme(plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        panel.background = element_blank(),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"))
```

**- How Does Time Usage Differ By U.S. Region?**
```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, fig.align='center'}
# time_jaeyeon_region for map
time_jaeyeon_region = time_jaeyeon_longer %>%
  group_by(REGION, STATE, TIME_ACTIVITY) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(TIME_SPENT)) %>%
  mutate(STATE = tolower(STATE)) %>%
  left_join(states %>%
              select(-subregion), 
            by = c('STATE' = 'region'))

# time_jaeyeon_region_text for map
time_jaeyeon_region_text = time_jaeyeon_longer %>%
  group_by(REGION, TIME_ACTIVITY) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(TIME_SPENT))

# Map
time_jaeyeon_region %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = long, y = lat, fill = REGION)) +
  geom_polygon(aes(group = group)) +
  coord_map(projection = "albers", lat0 = 39, lat1 = 45) +
  theme_map() +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = -75, y = 42.5, label = "Northeast", size = 4.5, fontface = "bold") +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = -95, y = 42.5, label = "Midwest", size = 5, fontface = "bold") +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = -90, y = 33.7, label = "South", size = 5, fontface = "bold") +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = -113.5, y = 41, label = "West", size = 5, fontface = "bold") +
  annotate("label", x = -53, y = 43, size = 3,
           label = "NORTHEAST \nEating & Drinking: 70.19 \nPersonal Care: 568.13 \nReligious Activities: 10.39 \nRelaxing & Leisure: 300.83 \nSports & Exercise: 19.40 \nTraveling: 74.21 \nWork Activities: 155.67") +
  annotate("label", x = -92, y = 55, size = 3,
           label = "MIDWEST \nEating & Drinking: 66.72 / Personal Care: 569.14 \nReligious Activities: 10.98 / Relaxing & Leisure: 299.32 \nSports & Exercise: 20.13 / Traveling: 69.28 \nWork Activities: 163.97") +
  annotate("label", x = -68, y = 28.8, size = 3,
           label = "SOUTH \nEating & Drinking: 64.15 \nPersonal Care: 583.75 \nReligious Activities: 16.26 \nRelaxing & Leisure: 302.88 \nSports & Exercise: 17.45 \nTraveling: 70.56 \nWork Activities: 155.97") +
  annotate("label", x = -134, y = 42, size = 3,
           label = "WEST \nEating & Drinking: 71.01 \nPersonal Care: 578.03 \nReligious Activities: 10.89 \nRelaxing & Leisure: 279.29 \nSports & Exercise: 22.41 \nTraveling: 72.58 \nWork Activities: 159.20") +
  labs(title = 'Map of the U.S. Regions with Average Time Spent on Each Activity Per Day',
       caption = 'Figure 4: Map of Average Time Spent per Day by Region (in minutes)',
       fill = 'Region') +
  theme(plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"))
```

## **Time Usage Over Time**

**- Has time spent engaged in religious and spiritual activities changed over the last 15 years?**
```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time %>% 
  rename(religion = ACT_RELIG) %>%
  ggplot(time, mapping = aes(x = YEAR, y = religion)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Year') +
  ylab('Total Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Time Usage Trend on Religious & Spiritual Activities (2004 - 2019)',
       caption = 'Figure 12: Time Usage Trend on Religious & Spiritual Activities (2004 - 2019)')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

The amount of time people spend participating in religious activities has remained stable since 2004. Every year, the majority is just below 500 minutes per day with a few outliers that spend much larger amounts of time, even going to 1000 minutes per day. Numbers have been relatively lower since 2013. 

**- Are Americans working more or less than they used to?**
```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
ggplot(time, mapping = aes(x = YEAR, y = ACT_WORK)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Year') +
  ylab('Total Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Time Usage Trend on Work & Work-Related Activities (2004 - 2019)',
       caption = 'Figure 13: Time Usage Trend on Work & Work-Related Activities (2004 - 2019)')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

The time spent working has also remained pretty stable since 2004. Most people spend at least 1000 minutes a day at work and many people spend up to 1500 minutes a day working. I did some math and realized that 1000 minutes a day equates to over 16.5 hours a day. This data set considers "work" to be activities physically at work, completing any work activities like going to lunch or playing golf with a client, doing anything that makes you money, applying for jobs or interviewing, and many other activities. Obviously not everyone works every single day for that long due to holidays, appointments, and vacations, but 16.5 hours a day is a baseline for lots of people in America. There is a slight dip in minutes worked in 2013, 2016, and 2018. There are many people spending zero minutes working per day which could be because of unemployed adults or children, as this data set includes people as young as 15.

**- How has time spent working changed in various regions of the U.S.?**
```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time$SEX <- factor(time$SEX, levels = c(1, 2), 
                 labels = c("M", "F"))

time$REGION <- factor(time$REGION, labels = c("Northeast", "Midwest", "South", "West"))

ggplot(time, aes(x = YEAR, y = ACT_WORK, fill = SEX)) + 
  facet_grid(~REGION) + 
  geom_bar(stat = 'identity') +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Year') +
  ylab('Total Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Time Usage Trend on Work & Work-Related Activities (2004 - 2019)',
       caption = 'Figure 14: Time Usage Trend on Work & Work-Related Activities by Region and Gender  (2004 - 2019)',
       fill = 'Gender')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

Across all regions, minutes per day spent working has been steadily decreasing since 2004. The decline seems to be similar across all regions, with no region seeing a more significant change than any other. The region with the people who work the most is the south. Again, work isn't only the traditional 9-5 in this data set- it includes any work related activities that can make money, applying/interviewing for jobs, or reading things for work at home. People in the south spend more time working than any other region by quite a significant amount. The midwest and the west have people who work similar amounts, and the northeast is where people spend the least amount of time working. I also included gender in my analysis. From what this plot shows, men and women work similar amounts in every region and they are both experiencing the same decline in time spent working since 2004.

## **Life Satisfaction & Time Usage**
The data in this portion was taken from removing all rows = null in the WBLADDER column. This analysis will show you peoples life satisfaction, work, and social activities around the United States.

**- In what ways do people spend their time?**


Each of these above graphs shows average minutes of time at each life quality that people reported for the activity. The most interesting graph of these to me is the Religious activities. There is a large drop off from the first bar where I would assume people are being forced to attend religious activites. Another interesting set would be Personal Care graph. Personal care includes sleep which will take up most of the personal care time. Based on this it shows that the more you sleep the lower your life satisfaction.

## **Health & Time Usage**

#### **Physical Activity**
The data provided in this dataset includes individuals ranging from 15-85 years of age. Specifically, this section of analysis explored the 'Sports' time use variable, which highlights the amount of time an individual spent on sports, exercise, and recreation in a day. This will be referenced as physical activity in the future.

**- Which age range spends the most time engaging in physical activity?**
```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
age <- time %>% 
  mutate(agegroup = case_when(AGE >= 15  & AGE <= 19 ~ '15-19',
                              AGE >= 20  & AGE <= 29 ~ '20-29',
                              AGE >= 30  & AGE <= 39 ~ '30-39',
                              AGE >= 40  & AGE <= 49 ~ '40-49',
                              AGE >= 50  & AGE <= 59 ~ '50-59',
                              AGE >= 60  & AGE <= 69 ~ '60-69',
                              AGE >= 70  & AGE <= 79 ~ '70-79',
                              AGE >= 80  & AGE <= 89 ~ '80-89',
                              AGE >= 20  & AGE <= 29 ~ '20-29'))

sportsByAge <- age %>%
  group_by(agegroup) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(ACT_SPORTS))

ggplot(sportsByAge, aes(x = agegroup, y = avg_time, fill = agegroup)) + geom_bar(stat = 'identity')  +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Age') +
  ylab('Average Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Average Active Time by Age',
       caption = "Figure 26: Average Active Time Spent by Age Group",
       fill = 'Age Group')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

The 15-19 year old group spends, on average, the greatest time doing sports, exercise and recreation - over double the amount of time compared to every other age group. Activity level tends to decline as age increases.

#### **BMI**
BMI, or Body Mass Index, is a measure of body fat based on height and weight that is commonly used in the healthcare setting. The BMI data was recorded in the ATUS survey series between 2006-2008 and 2014-2016. The BMI ranges (underweight, normal, overweight, and obese), are determined according to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) standard. It is important to note that BMI is NOT the most accurate predictor of health status, however, it is a useful tool and provides a general marker for individual health, especially on a large-scale level. More information on BMI can be found on the CDC's website (see works cited section for link). 
```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
bmi <- age %>%
  filter(YEAR == 2006 | YEAR == 2007 | YEAR == 2008 |
           YEAR == 2014 | YEAR == 2015 | YEAR == 2016) %>%
  filter(!is.na(BMI)) %>%
  filter(BMI < 500)

bmi$bmiStatus <- ifelse(bmi$BMI < 18.5, "underweight", 
                        ifelse(bmi$BMI < 25, "normal",
                        ifelse(bmi$BMI < 30, "overweight", 
                               "obese")))

ggplot(bmi, aes(x = BMI, fill = bmiStatus, color = bmiStatus)) + 
  geom_histogram(position = 'identity', bins = 30, alpha = 0.5) + 
  theme_bw() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#28C40C", "#DE2905", "#E8A201", "#8E9CA1")) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#28C40C", "#DE2905", "#E8A201", "#8E9CA1")) +
  xlab('BMI') +
  ylab('Number of Respondants') +
  labs(title = 'Distribution of BMI',
       caption = "Figure 29: Distribution of BMI Status")  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

This plot shows the distribution of BMI's among individuals. BMI status was calculated using the CDC standard and was manually added to the dataset. The most frequent BMI values occur at the higher end of the normal range and at the lower end of the overweight category.

#### **General Health**

One of the variables within the dataset contains self-reported general health status from the survey respnodents. The participants were asked to rate their general health as "Excellent," "Very good," "Good," "Fair," or "Poor." Some participants did refuse to answer and others responded "Don't know."

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
health <- bmi %>%
  filter(!is.na(GENHEALTH)) %>%
  filter(GENHEALTH != 99)
health$GENHEALTH <- factor(health$GENHEALTH, levels = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 96, 97), 
                     labels = c("Excellent", "Very good", "Good", "Fair", "Poor", "Refused", "Don't know"))

ggplot(health, aes(x = GENHEALTH, fill = GENHEALTH)) + 
  geom_bar() +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('General Health') +
  ylab('Number of Respondants') +
  labs(title = 'Distribution of Self-Reported General Health Status',
       caption = "Figure 31: Distribution of Self-Reported General Health Status",
       fill = 'Health Status')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

The general distribution is as shown above: A majority of respondents consider themselves in 'very good' or 'good' health. Interestingly, this slightly contradicts the BMI, objective measurement of health, where a larger majority of individuals are categorized as 'overweight.'

**- How does an individual's health (BMI and general health) relate to the amount of time they spend being physically active?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
bmiStatus <- bmi %>%
  mutate(bmiStatus = fct_relevel(bmiStatus, 
                            "underweight", "normal", "overweight", "obese")) %>%
  group_by(bmiStatus) %>%
  summarise(avg_active = mean(ACT_SPORTS))

ggplot(bmiStatus, aes(x = bmiStatus, y = avg_active, fill = bmiStatus)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = 'identity') +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('BMI Status') +
  ylab('Average Active Time per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Activity Levels by BMI Status',
       caption = "Figure 32: Activity Levels by BMI Status",
       fill = 'BMI Status')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```


```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
healthTable <- health %>%
  group_by(GENHEALTH) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(ACT_SPORTS))

ggplot(healthTable, aes(x = GENHEALTH, y = avg_time, fill = GENHEALTH)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = 'identity') +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('General Health') +
  ylab('Average Active Time per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Average Active Time by General Health Status',
       caption = "Figure 33: Average Active Time by General Health Status",
       fill = 'Health Status')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

Here, there is a general positive correlation between an individual's amount of activity time and their perceived health level. That is, those who consider themselves in good health tend to be more active. Is there a causal relationship? Do active individuals end up more healthy? Or are healthy individuals more able to complete physical activity?

## **Work-Life Balance**

**- How does an individual's work time correlate to their other activities?**

**- How does the presence or lack of children affect time-use?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
# change the 0/1 option for kids / no kids into a useful factor
time_jay <- time %>% mutate(kids = factor(ifelse(HH_CHILD==1,'children','no children')))

# we are going to bin the data of our time use data for analysis

breaks <- c(0,240,480,720,Inf)
labels <-c("0-3.99 hours", "4-7.99 hours", "8-11.99 hours", "12+ hours")
time_jay$work_time_bins <- cut(time_jay$ACT_WORK, breaks = breaks, labels = labels, right=FALSE)

breaks <- c(0,120,240,360,480,Inf)
labels <-c("0-1.99 hours", "2-3.99 hours", "4-5.99 hours", "6-7.99 hours","8+")
time_jay$travel_time_bins <- cut(time_jay$ACT_TRAVEL, breaks = breaks, labels = labels, right=FALSE)


breaks <- c(0,30,60,90,Inf)
labels <-c("0-29 minutes", "30-59 minutes", "60-89 minutes", "90+ minutes")
time_jay$relig_time_bins <- cut(time_jay$ACT_RELIG, breaks = breaks, labels = labels, right=FALSE)

breaks <- c(0,60,120,180,240,Inf)
labels <-c("0-59 minutes", "60-119 minutes", "120-179 minutes", "180-239 minutes"," 240+")
time_jay$social_time_bins <- cut(time_jay$ACT_SOCIAL, breaks = breaks, labels = labels, right=FALSE)
```

In the IPUMS data, a day is considered 4am to 3:59am the following morning. Respondants are supposedly logging time use details in a diary which is then collated into a huge data set online, which we are able to subset into desired variables via a web interface. 

In order to better visualize how the data is shaped between respondants with children and those without, we created discrete bins of the time data for several catagories: Time spent working, time spent traveling, time spent in religous activities, and time spent in social activities. We tried to break the discrete time values up into units which we felt reasonable, based on some quick data explorations when we first received the data set. 

We also changed the 1 or 0 values under the "Children in the household" variable, HH_CHILD, to "children" and "no children."

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
#some quick means for the groups, just to see
time_jay %>% group_by(kids) %>% summarise(n=n(),
                                                  mean_act_work = mean(ACT_WORK),
                                                  mean_act_social = mean(ACT_SOCIAL),
                                                  mean_act_relig = mean(ACT_RELIG),
                                                  mean_act_travel = mean(ACT_TRAVEL))
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, fig.align='default', fig.show="hold", out.width="50%"}
time_jay %>%  
  filter(ACT_SOCIAL>0) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = kids, y = ACT_SOCIAL, fill = kids)) + 
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Children Status') +
  ylab('Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Time Spent on Socializing, Relaxing & Leisure by Children Status',
       caption = "Figure 34: Time Spent on Socializing, Relaxing & Leisure by Children Status",
       fill = 'Children Status')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

time_jay %>% 
  filter(ACT_RELIG > 0) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = kids, y = ACT_RELIG, fill = kids)) + 
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Children Status') +
  ylab('Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Time Spent on Religious & Spiritual Activities by Children Status',
       caption = "Figure 35: Time Spent on Religious & Spiritual Activities by Children Status",
       fill = 'Children Status')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, fig.align='center', fig.show="hold", out.width="50%"}
time_jay %>%  filter(ACT_TRAVEL>0) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = kids, y = ACT_TRAVEL, fill = kids)) + 
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Children Status') +
  ylab('Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Time Spent on Traveling by Children Status',
       caption = "Figure 36: Time Spent on Traveling by Children Status",
       fill = 'Children Status')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

Figure 34 shows the distribution of minutes spent in social time, excluding respondant who reported 0 social time. Figure 35 shows the reported time spent enaged in religious activities by people who reported more than 0 minutes per day engaged in religious activities. Figure 36 shows the time spent on traveling by children status. There are a lot of outliers in this boxplot of ACT_TRAVEL time between those with children and those without. . How much time can one really travel in a day?


#kids & work#

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time_jay %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=work_time_bins, y=ACT_WORK)) + geom_boxplot(aes(color=kids)) + ggtitle("Boxplot of minutes worked daily by child status") + xlab('Reported Daily Hours') + ylab('Minutes worked')


time_jay %>% 
  group_by(kids, work_time_bins) %>% 
  summarize(n = n(), mean_work_minutes = mean(ACT_WORK))

time_jay %>% 
  group_by(kids, work_time_bins) %>% 
  summarize(n = n(), mean_work_minutes = mean(ACT_WORK)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=work_time_bins, y=mean_work_minutes)) + 
  geom_linerange(aes(x=work_time_bins, ymin=0, ymax=mean_work_minutes, group=kids), 
                 color="lightgray", 
                 position=position_dodge(0.3), 
                 size=1.5) + 
  geom_point(aes(color=kids), position=position_dodge(0.3), size=3) + 
  theme_pubclean() + 
  ggtitle("Average minutes worked by daily hours and child status") + 
  ylab("Mean minutes worked per day") + xlab("Reported daily hours worked")


```

We broke the amount people worked into three bins, essentially less than half time, half time to full time, and over-time workers, and determined the mean minutes worked for both households with children and households without. The boxplot shows the distribution of our data and the second plot nicely visualizes how much time each group spends compard to the other. This appears to indicate that for the most parts across our time-worked bins, households with and households without children have similar mean minutes spent working per day.

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
                 position=position_dodge(0.3), 
                 size=1.5) + 
  geom_point(aes(color=kids), position=position_dodge(0.3), size=3) + 
  theme_pubclean() + 
  ggtitle("Average minutes traveld by daily hours and child status") + 
  ylab("Mean minutes traveling per day") + xlab("Reported daily hours traveling")

```

Our boxplot shows how the data is distributed across the time spent. Our second box seems to indicate that family with children report slightly more time spent travelling than the no children group.

#kids & religious# 

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time_jay  %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=relig_time_bins, y=ACT_RELIG)) + geom_boxplot(aes(color=kids)) + ggtitle(label="Boxplot of minutes religious daily by child status", subtitle="subtitle") + xlab('Binned times') + ylab('Minutes religious')


time_jay %>% 
  group_by(kids, relig_time_bins) %>% 
  summarize(n = n(), mean_relig_minutes = mean(ACT_RELIG))


time_jay %>% 
  group_by(kids, relig_time_bins) %>% 
  summarize(n = n(), mean_relig_minutes = mean(ACT_RELIG)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=relig_time_bins, y=mean_relig_minutes)) + 
  geom_linerange(aes(x=relig_time_bins, ymin=0, ymax=mean_relig_minutes, group=kids), 
                 color="lightgray", 
                 position=position_dodge(0.3), 
                 size=1.5) + 
  geom_point(aes(color=kids), position=position_dodge(0.3), size=3) +

  ggtitle("Average minutes religious by daily hours and child status") +

```

The boxplot here is interesting to us in that there are a lot of possible outlier data above the 90 minuets a day mark. Perhaps this category would be better served by adding another block of time at two hours or above? Again, both plots show roughly equal time spent between those with and without children, except in the 90+ minute block, which shows a higher mean for those with no children.

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time_jay  %>%
```

These plots are about time spent in social activities between those with and without children. The large number of outliers indicate to us that maybe another time block above four hours might be in order. In four of the catagories the mean time spent in social activity the mean minutes are roughly equal, but in the catagory of four or more hours per day there is a clear difference in the means between those with and those without children. We should probably not be surprised by this. 


<h3>Relationships between times</h3>



```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}


# this is a very ugly plot! too many data points!!!
time_jay %>%  ggplot(aes(x=ACT_WORK, y=ACT_TRAVEL, color = kids)) + geom_point() + ggtitle("Work vs Travel") +ylab("Minutes traveling") + xlab("Minutes working")

```
This plot is not good. There are twoo many data points too closely packed together. But it attempts to show a relation between minutes spent traveling and minutes spent working. 



```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}

time_jay %>%  ggplot(aes(x=ACT_WORK, y=ACT_TRAVEL, color = kids)) + 
  geom_smooth(method=lm) + 
  ggtitle(label="Work minutes by Travel minutes") +
  xlab("Daily Minutes WORK") + ylab("Daily Minutes TRAVEL") + coord_cartesian(ylim=c(40,100),xlim=c(0,1400))
```

By using a regression line on our data, we might be able to better estimate how respondants use their time and look for signs of interaction or correlatoin between our variables. In this plot we see that respondans with children report about the same amount of travel time as time spent working increases. But for respondants with no children, there is a  steeper slope indicating that more time working might correlate to more time spent travelling. 



```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time_jay %>%  ggplot(aes(x=ACT_WORK, y=ACT_RELIG, color = kids)) + 
  geom_smooth(method=lm) + 
  ggtitle(label="Work mintues by Religious minutes") +
  xlab("Daily Minutes WORK") + ylab("Daily Minutes RELIG") + coord_cartesian(ylim=c(0,30),xlim=c(0,1400)) 

```



```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time_jay %>%  ggplot(aes(x=ACT_WORK, y=ACT_SOCIAL, color = kids)) + 
  geom_smooth(method=lm) + 
  ggtitle(label="Work mintues by Social minutes") +
  xlab("Daily Minutes WORK") + ylab("Daily Minutes SOCIAL") + coord_cartesian(ylim=c(0,400),xlim=c(0,1400))

```

Among both respondants with children and those without, as minutes work increases, the amount of social time decreases.



<h3>Possible correlations?</h3>
```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time_jay %>% 
  filter(kids=="no children") %>% 
  select(ACT_WORK, ACT_SOCIAL, ACT_TRAVEL, ACT_RELIG) %>% 
  cor() %>% 
  ggcorrplot(method="square", lab=TRUE) + 
  ggtitle("Correlation matrix - No Children")
```

We can use R to create a correlation matrix of our time-based variables. Among the no children group, there appears a moderate negative relation between work and social minutes, indicating that as minutes in work increase, minutes engaged in social time decrease. We should not be surprised at this based on the example charts from above. 


```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}x
# a correlation matrix of our time data, with kids, for work =0
time_jay %>% 
  filter(kids=="children") %>% 
  select(ACT_WORK, ACT_SOCIAL, ACT_TRAVEL, ACT_RELIG) %>% 
  cor() %>% 
  ggcorrplot(method="square", lab=TRUE) + 
  ggtitle("Correlation matrix - Children")

```

Removing children from the data set for our correlation only slightly lowers the strength of the possible correlations between our categories. Again, we should not be be surprised at this conclusion based on the previous charts we examined.

## **Conclusion**

The IPUMS Time-Use data set covers a wide range of social topics and demographics with the ability to create and download a data-set customized to your own needs. 

<h4>Time Usage Over Time</h4>
Time spent doing religious activities has decreased and time spent working has also decreased an equal amount across all regions in the U.S. 
<h4>Life Satisfaction & Time Usage</h4>
The more a person can diversify their daily activities the greater their perceived life satisfaction will be 
<h4>Health & Time Usage</h4>
increased physical activity does not necessarily correlate to healthier BMI - other factors (nutrition, etc) must be involved
<h4>Work-Life Balance</h4>
Household with and without children, on the average, spend the same amount of time on the activities we examined.
Work and social time have a negative correlation, work and the other activities have little correlation.
